title: 107_hr1181
content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is a new law that provides a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" offers a tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage paid by individuals, limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for up to two individuals. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to 2 individuals per taxpayer. Married individuals who do not file a joint return and do not live apart from their spouse can only count themselves for the credit. An eligible coverage month is when an individual is covered by qualified health insurance paid by the taxpayer. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited to individuals covered by insurance paid by the taxpayer, with specific criteria for eligibility and limitations based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited to individuals covered by insurance paid by the taxpayer, with specific criteria for eligibility and limitations based on adjusted gross income. The amount of reduction is determined based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year, with rounding rules applied. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited to individuals covered by insurance paid by the taxpayer, with specific criteria for eligibility and limitations based on adjusted gross income. The reduction amount is determined based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with rounding rules applied to amounts not multiples of $10. The applicable dollar amount varies based on the number of individuals covered and marital status, with marital status determined under section 7703. Qualified health insurance is defined as insurance constituting medical care, excluding insurance if substantially all. The term 'qualified health insurance' refers to insurance that constitutes medical care, excluding coverage where less than 50 percent of the cost is borne by the taxpayer. The tax credit does not apply to amounts paid under specific government-provided programs. The tax credit for qualified health insurance does not apply if the cost is covered by specific government programs like those outlined in chapters 55 of title 10, chapter 17 of title 38, or the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. Coverage under these provisions is considered as qualified health insurance for eligibility purposes. Special rules include coordination with other deductions and denial of credit to dependents if a deduction is allowable to another taxpayer. Inflation adjustments are made to dollar amounts in subsections (b)(2)(A) and (c)(3) for taxable years beginning after 2002. The adjustment is based on the cost-of-living increase determined for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. Amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of $100 if not already a multiple. "Inflation adjustments are made to dollar amounts in subsections for taxable years beginning after 2002. Amounts are rounded to the next lowest multiple of $100 if necessary." The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on costs of qualified health insurance. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules apply, such as not double counting the deduction with other medical expenses. The deduction is not allowed for self-employment tax purposes. Conforming amendments include adding a new item for the deduction in the Internal Revenue Code. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for the costs of qualified health insurance. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for the costs of qualified health insurance, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
